As a nurse that specializes as a hydration coach in sports and life, the thing you say about thirst as your guide is wrong.

Yes, never more than 32 ounces in 2 hours. But, we need electrolytes. My runners and athletes eat about 1/16th tsp of unprocessed salt dissolved in the mouth just before drinking.

We recommend about 0.08 x your body weight every 2 hours. Don't  nurse it, drink all at once.

Using thirst is a poor and late indicator of hydration needs. This because our bodies always balance water needs until we reach the tipping point. Then it is not only too late, it takes much longer to rehydrate as the body is out of balance. Although new in sports hydration coaching, my athletes are often the ones that out preform the others.

They should have mentioned not just endurance sports as being a risk factor, but water consuming competitions, dares, or even parents punishing their kids. Yes, these do happen, because many people don't understand how this could hurt them and just how much water can cause death. There was a radio station in Sacramento several years ago that had a "Hold your wee for a Wii" contest, and one of the contestants died, despite the fact that nurses, doctors, and scientists were calling in telling them to stop the contest (the D.J.s just made fun of them). This kind of thing also happens during hazing for fraternities. There was also a case when a child spilled some juice on the floor, so as punishment her mother forced her to drink all the juice they had left, and when they ran out of that she forced her to continue drinking water until she died (sick bastard of a mother, if you ask me). This is just one reason why public science education is important.

Yes you can die, it's known as dilutional hyponatremia. And for the average adult you need around 64 oz daily. That is NOT 8, 8oz glasses of water, but any water - which the average person easily attains through the foods they eat - there's water in everything you consume. The myth started back in the 50's when the American Food Council said you need 64oz per day. And they also stipulated that most adults get this in what they eat per day, but somehow that got forgotten and people latched onto the idea you need 8 glasses per day. Your body overall does the best job of letting you know when you're dehydrated.

When you are thirsty you are already dehydrated. If there's one thing i learned early on during my time in the Military it was to drink often BEFORE you got thirsty, drink after taking a piss. Drink if you sweat. Drink if you have spare time (which you rarely do) and drink before going to sleep/after waking up.

The moment you feel thirst it's already too late in that environment, you are dehydrated and will constantly be playing the catch-up game until you have a day's rest.

I still follow that regime as much as i can, i drink BEFORE i get thirsty and i drink ahead of time because the water you drink now will only benefit you many hours later.
